DataElement.preferredName: Preoperative Diagnostic Imaging Maximum Malignant Neoplasm Diameter Present Status
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the maximum (the largest possible quantity or degree) tumor (composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues) diameter (the length of a straight line that extends from one edge of a tumor through its center and to the opposite edge) and preoperative (relating to or occurring during the period immediately before a surgical operation) diagnostic imaging (any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues using radiation, such as x-rays, or other imaging technologies such as magnetic resonance imaging).

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information relating to the maximum (the largest possible quantity or degree) tumor (composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues) diameter (the length of a straight line that extends from one edge of a tumor through its center and to the opposite edge) and preoperative (relating to or occurring during the period immediately before a surgical operation) diagnostic imaging (any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues using radiation, such as x-rays, or other imaging technologies such as magnetic resonance imaging).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Relating to or occurring during the period immediately before a surgical operation. :Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation..

Concepts.definition: Relating to or occurring during the period immediately before a surgical operation.
Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation.

Property.preferredDefinition: the largest possible quantity or degree.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:The length of a straight line that extends from one edge of a tumor or other object,  through its center and to the opposite edge.  It is  usually used to measure the size of round or spherical shapes.:Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

Concepts.definition: The largest possible quantity or degree.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

The length of a straight line that extends from one edge of a tumor or other object,  through its center and to the opposite edge.  It is  usually used to measure the size of round or spherical shapes.
Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: any measurements, including linear dimensions, volume, and weight, of a patient's tumor.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the maximum diameter of a malignant neoplasm at a particular time.
